DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the aplastic anemia classification.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Anemia resulting from bone marrow failure (aplastic or hypoplastic bone marrow).  The production of erythroblasts and red cells is markedly decreased, and it may be associated with decreased production of granulocytes (granulocytopenia) and platelets (thrombocytopenia) as well.  Aplastic anemia may be idiopathic or secondary due to bone marrow damage by toxins, radiation, or immunologic factors. -- 2004 _A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A condition in which the bone marrow is unable to produce blood cells.

Concepts.definition: Anemia resulting from bone marrow failure (aplastic or hypoplastic bone marrow). The production of erythroblasts and red cells is markedly decreased, and it may be associated with decreased production of granulocytes (granulocytopenia) and platelets (thrombocytopenia) as well. Aplastic anemia may be idiopathic or secondary due to bone marrow damage by toxins, radiation, or immunologic factors.

Property.preferredDefinition: Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

Aplastic anemia may be idiopathic or secondary due to bone marrow damage by toxins, radiation, or immunologic factors._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

PermissibleValues.value: Acquired AA secondary to immunotherapy or immune effector cell therapy
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Secondary To Immunotherapy Or Effector Immune Cell Therapeutic Procedure Aplastic Anemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Secondary To Immunotherapy Or Effector Immune Cell Therapeutic Procedure Aplastic Anemia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.: Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.: Therapy designed to induce changes in a patient's immune status in order to treat disease.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: An immune cell, usually a T- or B- lymphocyte, that is responding to an antigen exposure.: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.: A condition in which the bone marrow is unable to produce blood cells.

Concepts.definition: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
Therapy designed to induce changes in a patient's immune status in order to treat disease.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
An immune cell, usually a T- or B- lymphocyte, that is responding to an antigen exposure.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

Anemia resulting from bone marrow failure (aplastic or hypoplastic bone marrow). The production of erythroblasts and red cells is markedly decreased, and it may be associated with decreased production of granulocytes (granulocytopenia) and platelets (thrombocytopenia) as well. Aplastic anemia may be idiopathic or secondary due to bone marrow damage by toxins, radiation, or immunologic factors.

Concepts.definition: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases.

Anemia resulting from bone marrow failure (aplastic or hypoplastic bone marrow). The production of erythroblasts and red cells is markedly decreased, and it may be associated with decreased production of granulocytes (granulocytopenia) and platelets (thrombocytopenia) as well. Aplastic anemia may be idiopathic or secondary due to bone marrow damage by toxins, radiation, or immunologic factors.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction._Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells._A non-neoplastic, congenital or non-congenital disorder charcaterized by marked reduction or absence of megakaryocytes and thrombocytopenia.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells.
A non-neoplastic, congenital or non-congenital disorder charcaterized by marked reduction or absence of megakaryocytes and thrombocytopenia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Bone marrow failure defined as pancytopenia, secondary to hepatitis.

Concepts.definition: Bone marrow failure defined as pancytopenia, secondary to hepatitis.

PermissibleValues.value: Acquired AA, secondary to toxin / other drug

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A state of bone marrow suppression and failure that is caused by a cytotoxic or adverse immunologic response to a drug treatment, leading to a failure of production of red blood cells, white cells and platelets.

Concepts.definition: A state of bone marrow suppression and failure that is caused by a cytotoxic or adverse immunologic response to a drug treatment, leading to a failure of production of red blood cells, white cells and platelets.

PermissibleValues.value: Acquired pure red cell aplasia (not congenital)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disease characterized by normocytic, normochromic anemia, low hematocrit, reticulocytopenia and selective erythroid hypoplasia. It can occur as a chronic or acute form; the former is predominantly seen in adults and the latter in children.  Pathogenesis involves immune dysfunction with antibodies directed against erythroid precursor cells or erythropoietin, or due to T-cell mediated suppression of erythropoiesis.

Concepts.definition: A disease characterized by normocytic, normochromic anemia, low hematocrit, reticulocytopenia and selective erythroid hypoplasia. It can occur as a chronic or acute form; the former is predominantly seen in adults and the latter in children. Pathogenesis involves immune dysfunction with antibodies directed against erythroid precursor cells or erythropoietin, or due to T-cell mediated suppression of erythropoiesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Of or relating to a medical condition or characteristic that is not present at birth and develops subsequently.: A reduction in the number of blood cells.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Of or relating to a medical condition or characteristic that is not present at birth but develops subsequently.
A laboratory test result indicating an abnormally low quantity of circulating blood cells.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Not Otherwise Specified Acquired Aplastic Anemia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Not Otherwise Specified Acquired Aplastic Anemia

Concepts.definition: Not characterized in any other way.
Of or relating to a medical condition or characteristic that is not present at birth but develops subsequently.

Anemia resulting from bone marrow failure (aplastic or hypoplastic bone marrow). The production of erythroblasts and red cells is markedly decreased, and it may be associated with decreased production of granulocytes (granulocytopenia) and platelets (thrombocytopenia) as well. Aplastic anemia may be idiopathic or secondary due to bone marrow damage by toxins, radiation, or immunologic factors.
